item.title: An Interview with Mayor of London candidate George Galloway
item.author: Joshua Renken,
item.description: Born in Dundee, Galloway became involved in politics from a very young age and is now campaigning as RESPECT Party candidate for Mayor of London. Known as a political maverick and divisive figure in British politics, Galloway has been lauded for his lively rhetoric and impassioned debating style. …

item.title: In conversation with the author, documentary maker and popular philosopher, Alain de Botton
item.author: Joshua Renken,
item.description: There are not many people who can say they have set up an international school, written books that have been bestsellers in 30 countries, and given two TED talks. Fewer still can say they have re-hung an art museum and worked as Heathrow airport’s first ever writer-in-residence – but the author, …

item.title: The leadership races to watch over the Summer
item.author: Joshua Renken,
item.description: Four candidates will be on the ballot paper when Labour Party members get to vote on Ed Miliband’s successor in September. item.title: Talking to physicist Brandon Brown, author of ‘Max Planck: Driven by Vision, Broken by War’

item.description: Brandon Brown has spent his career teaching Physics. item.title: Do we need electoral reform?
item.author: Joshua Renken,
item.description: The election is finally over. It was a tightly contested campaign but in the end, the Tories carried the day. The final tally put the Conservatives on a slim majority, and sent Labour back to the opposition benches for another five years. The country has moved further to the right, which ironically …

item.title: Our future: as told by Her Majesty
item.author: Joshua Renken,
item.description: On Wednesday the 27th May, 20 days after the general election, the Queen outlined the proposed legislation of the new government. item.title: Ireland votes “Yes" to legalising same-sex marriage
item.author: Joshua Renken,
item.description: Ireland has made history as the first country in the world to legalise same-sex marriage by popular vote. Over 3.2 million people were asked whether they wanted to amend Ireland’s constitution to allow gay and lesbian couples to marry, in a referendum asking the electorate to vote “Yes” or “No” to …

Captured by the ‘War Boys’ - led by King Immortan Joe (Hugh …

Protestors threw traffic cones, smoke bombs and other objects at the police in central London, angry that the Conservatives won …

item.title: An interview with Andy Slaughter MP

item.description: The Labour politician Andy Slaughter was elected as Member of Parliament for Hammersmith in 2010, and was re-elected last week with 50% of the vote. Previously the MP for Ealing, Acton and Shepherd’s Bush from 2005 to 2010, Slaughter has been the Shadow Justice Minister since 2010, serving on the …

Thousands gathered in the impromptu protests, where Officers in riot gear clashed with a “minority” of protesters who were demonstrating …

item.title: Cameron’s reshuffled cabinet: the big hitters in government
item.author: Joshua Renken,
item.description: There’s not much change at the top in Cameron’s cabinet reshuffle, but in the ‘bottom’ half there are far more young and fresh faces, including more women. This punchy, more camera friendly cabinet is designed to show the changing face of the conservative government, and full of people who may prove …

item.title: Nigel Farage remains UKIP leader after the party rejects his resignation

item.description: Love him or hate him, you’ll be seeing even more of Nigel Farage in the near future. On 8th May Nigel Farage offered his resignation to the United Kingdom Independence Party’s National Executive Committee (UKIP’s ruling board), which was rejected on 11th May. item.title: General Election 2015: the winners and losers
item.author: Joshua Renken,

item.title: Just how do you decide who to vote for?
item.author: Joshua Renken,
item.description: The novelist and essayist George Orwell once said that political language is “designed to make lies sound truthful and murder respectable, and to give an appearance of solidity to pure wind.” He wrote that over half a century ago, but it is just as relevant today as it was then. Perhaps even more …

item.title: Election 2015: Labour versus Conservative policies
item.author: Joshua Renken,
item.description: Regardless of the precise results of this May’s general election, only two men are in with a chance of leading the country over the next parliament: the incumbent Prime Minister David Cameron or the Leader of the Opposition Ed Miliband. In the last five years we have seen a surge in support for …

item.description: Hillary Clinton has officially announced her candidacy for the US Democratic presidential nomination in 2016, confirming years of speculation that she would run a second time after losing the nomination in 2008 to Barack Obama. item.description: If you have never watched House, I envy you. It is one of the most nuanced and intelligent shows ever created, and there are 177 episodes for you to enjoy for the first time. item.title: How do you like your tea?
item.author: Joshua Renken,
item.description: A fresh cup of English Breakfast tea is truly something to behold. It is the liquid of the Gods and the chosen tipple of this great nation. item.title: Why don’t more young people vote?
item.author: Joshua Renken,
item.description: With just 61 days to go until polling stations open across the United Kingdom, party election campaigns are well under way. In 2010, voter turnout was at 65%. The over-65’s demographic had an overall turnout of 76%. Amongst 18-24 year olds, however, turnout was only 44% and recent polls indicate …

item.author: Joshua Renken,

Britain appears to be entering an era of six-party politics, where …

item.title: Brooklyn Nine-Nine: For Your Consideration
item.author: Joshua Renken,
item.description: Sitcoms are notoriously hard to get right; and cop genre comedies especially so. TV history is full of huge success stories and miserable failures. item.title: Charlie Hebdo just isn’t funny enough
item.author: Joshua Renken,
item.description: Let’s face it, 2014 was not a great year. Tragedies ranging from epidemics to political tension to aviation mysteries to religious extremism defined those twelve depressing months. Even the supposed sporting highlights were overshadowed by allegations of greed and corruption. At best, it was a …
